parent_formation: Comando Superiore Forze Armate Africa Settentrionale (North Africa)

commander.name: Generale d'Armata Giuseppe Tellera
commander.notes: Served December 23, 1940 - February 7, 1941. Killed in action at Battle of Beda Fomm, February 7, 1941. Predecessors: Generale d'Armata Italo Gariboldi (until November 17, 1940), Generale d'Armata Mario Berti (November 17 - December 23, 1940)

location: Cyrenaica, Libya (retreating from Egyptian border to Beda Fomm)
historical_context: Operation Compass - British offensive that destroyed 10th Army
personnel_notes: Personnel strength declined throughout Q1 1941 due to British Operation Compass offensive. Starting strength ~130,000 (January 1), ending strength ~15,000 survivors (February 7 at Beda Fomm). Snapshot represents mid-January before final collapse. Approximately 130,000 casualties/POWs by end of battle February 7, 1941.

3.notes: Limited numbers with specialists and officers, 9x19mm

tanks.notes: Tank strength significantly depleted during Operation Compass. Most M11/39 and M13/40 tanks destroyed or captured. Maletti Group destroyed December 1940. Babini Armored Brigade severely mauled. Final tank battle at Beda Fomm February 5-7 destroyed remaining armor.

ground_vehicles_notes: Vehicle strength declining due to attrition, mechanical breakdowns, and fuel shortages during retreat. Many vehicles abandoned during withdrawal to Beda Fomm.
aircraft_notes: 10th Army had no organic aircraft. Air support provided by Regia Aeronautica units under separate command (not included in army TO&E).

subordinate_units.commander: Generale di Corpo d'Armata Annibale Bergonzoli ('Electric Whiskers')
subordinate_units.location: Eastern Cyrenaica / Bardia sector / Eventually surrounded at Tobruk
composition: Frontier Guard Units and Fortress Troops in Bardia
subordinate_units.notes: Primary defensive corps. Heavily engaged December 1940 - January 1941. Suffered catastrophic losses. Raggruppamento Maletti destroyed at Nibeiwa December 9, 1940. Bardia garrison fell January 5, 1941. Tobruk garrison captured January 22, 1941. Corps effectively destroyed by end January.

subordinate_units.commander: Generale di Corpo d'Armata Petassi Mannella
composition: Fortress Troops and Artillery in Tobruk
subordinate_units.notes: Tobruk fortress garrison. Captured by British forces January 22, 1941 during Operation Compass. Approximately 25,000 POWs including corps commander.

subordinate_units.commander: Generale di Corpo d'Armata Giuseppe Cona
subordinate_units.location: Western Cyrenaica / Retreating toward Beda Fomm
composition: Brigata Corazzata Speciale (Special Armored Brigade - Babini)
subordinate_units.notes: Mobile reserve corps. Retreated from Derna toward Benghazi. Destroyed at Battle of Beda Fomm February 5-7, 1941. Babini Armored Brigade (1st, 3rd M11 battalions, 21st, 60th L3 battalions, Bersaglieri) severely mauled and effectively destroyed.
Colonial division with Libyan troops. 1st and 2nd Raggruppamenti Lybian Infantry. Destroyed during Operation Compass.
Colonial division. Destroyed during Operation Compass December 1940 - January 1941.
Blackshirt (Fascist militia) division. Lower combat effectiveness than regular army divisions. Destroyed during Operation Compass.

DESTROYED December 9, 1940 at Battle of Nibeiwa. First engagement of Operation Compass. Commander Generale Pietro Maletti killed. Entire unit destroyed or captured. Listed for historical completeness only - not part of effective January 1941 strength.
Regular metropolitan infantry division. Heavy combat during Operation Compass. Significant casualties.
Regular metropolitan infantry division. Destroyed during Operation Compass.
Regular metropolitan infantry division. Destroyed during Operation Compass.

composition: Fortress Troops and Artillery in Tobruk
subordinate_units.notes: Tobruk garrison division. Captured January 22, 1941. Approximately 25,000 POWs including garrison and fortress troops.
Regular metropolitan infantry division. Destroyed at Beda Fomm February 5-7, 1941.
Motorized (autotrasportabile) division - truck-mobile infantry. Better mobility than standard infantry divisions. Destroyed at Beda Fomm February 5-7, 1941.
Regular metropolitan infantry division. Destroyed at Beda Fomm February 5-7, 1941.

Armored reserve brigade. Severely mauled in battles around Mechili and Derna January 1941. Remnants destroyed at Beda Fomm February 5-7, 1941. Primary Italian armored force in Cyrenaica after Maletti Group destruction.

supply_bottlenecks: British air superiority disrupting supply convoys
Mediterranean shipping losses to Royal Navy and RAF
Long overland supply lines from Tripoli and Benghazi
Fuel shortages critically limiting mobility during retreat
Ammunition stocks depleted by heavy combat
Water scarcity in desert critical constraint
Vehicle breakdowns due to lack of spare parts
supply_logistics.supply_notes: Supply situation catastrophic by January 1941. British Operation Compass severely disrupted logistics. Retreating units abandoned equipment and supplies. Fuel shortages prevented effective withdrawal. By Beda Fomm (February 5-7), army had effectively collapsed logistically.

weather_environment.visibility: Generally excellent except during occasional sandstorms
weather_environment.weather_impact: Winter weather relatively mild compared to summer. Occasional rains created mud and impeded movement. Good visibility favored British air superiority. Cold nights affected morale of troops lacking adequate winter clothing.
weather_environment.terrain_impact: Coastal escarpment provided some defensive positions but British outflanked via desert. Wadis (dry riverbeds) channelized movement. Open desert terrain favored mechanized forces and British armor superiority. Limited water sources critical constraint.

experience_level: Declining - Heavy casualties among experienced personnel
tactical_situation: CATASTROPHIC DEFEAT IN PROGRESS. 10th Army undergoing complete destruction during British Operation Compass (December 9, 1940 - February 7, 1941). Initial British attack at Nibeiwa (Dec 9) destroyed Maletti Group. Sidi Barrani fell Dec 10. XXI Corps shattered. Bardia fortress fell January 5 (45,000 POWs). Tobruk fortress fell January 22 (25,000 POWs). Remaining forces retreating toward El Agheila. British 7th Armoured Division cut off retreat at Beda Fomm February 5-7. 10th Army commander Generale Tellera killed February 7. Approximately 130,000 casualties/POWs, 400 tanks destroyed/captured, 845 guns lost. Army effectively ceased to exist as cohesive force by February 7, 1941.
historical_notes: Operation Compass launched December 9, 1940 as British 'five-day raid' - became complete destruction of 10th Army
Raggruppamento Maletti destroyed at Nibeiwa, December 9, 1940 - Commander Generale Maletti killed
Bardia fortress fell January 5, 1941 - 45,000 Italian POWs
Tobruk fortress fell January 22, 1941 - 25,000 Italian POWs including XXII Corps commander
British 7th Armoured Division cut Italian retreat at Beda Fomm, February 5, 1941
Battle of Beda Fomm, February 5-7, 1941 - Final destruction of 10th Army
Generale Giuseppe Tellera killed in action February 7, 1941
Generale Annibale 'Electric Whiskers' Bergonzoli (XXI Corps) captured
Total losses: ~130,000 casualties/POWs, ~400 tanks, ~845 artillery pieces
British losses: ~500 killed, ~1,400 wounded, ~55 tanks damaged
10th Army reformed later in 1941 with fresh units from Italy
Victory established British control of Cyrenaica until Rommel's arrival (March 1941)

source_notes.source_name: Nafziger Collection - 940ILAA: Italian Forces, Battle of Sidi el Barrani, 9-11 December 1940
source_notes.notes: Detailed TO&E for 10th Army at start of Operation Compass. Provides complete organization for XXI Corps, Libyan Divisions, CCNN divisions, Maletti Group. Equipment allocations by battalion/battery level. Commander: Generale Italo Gariboldi.

source_notes.source_name: Nafziger Collection - 940ILAB: Italian Forces in North Africa, Operation Compass, 1 November 1940 - February 1941
source_notes.notes: Complete organizational structure for all three corps (XXI, XXII, XX). Lists all divisions by corps. Commanders: Gariboldi (until 11/17/40), Berti (until 12/23/40), Tellera (died 2/7/41). Provides 27th Brescia (motorized) and 17th Pavia divisions organization. Babini Armored Brigade composition.

source_notes.source_name: Barrie Pitt, The Crucible of War: Western Desert 1941
source_notes.notes: Cited in Nafziger document. Comprehensive operational history of Operation Compass. Battle chronology, casualties, command decisions.

source_notes.source_name: Victor Madej, Italian Army Order of Battle, 1939-1943
source_notes.notes: Cited in Nafziger document. Authoritative reference on Italian army organization and equipment.

source_notes.source_name: US Government, Notes on Enemy Army Identifications, Italy, October 1941
source_notes.notes: Cited in Nafziger document. Contemporary US military intelligence assessment of Italian forces.

source_notes.source_name: Personnel and equipment totals aggregated from subordinate units
source_notes.notes: Army-level totals calculated from division/brigade TO&E provided in source documents. Some estimation required for corps troops and army-level assets.

organizational_summary.unit_composition: Aggregate calculated from known unit strengths (March 1941). 7 gruppi identified with specific aircraft counts.

data_source.extraction_method: Unit-level strength compilation from online sources

validation.source_quality: Excellent - Multiple primary Nafziger Collection documents with detailed battalion-level organization
validation.cross_reference_validation: Organization cross-referenced between 940ILAA (December 1940 battle) and 940ILAB (November 1940 - February 1941 campaign)
gaps: Exact strength figures for some divisions on January 1, 1941 (used December 1940 data as baseline)
Chief of Staff identity not specified in sources
Corps-level troops (artillery, engineers, signals) not fully detailed
Air force units supporting 10th Army (under separate Regia Aeronautica command)
Precise daily casualty/attrition rates during Operation Compass
Exact tank allocations by battalion for Babini Brigade (estimated from source totals)
Fortress troop details for Bardia and Tobruk garrisons (strengths estimated)
validation.historical_accuracy_notes: TO&E represents January 1-15, 1941 snapshot during Operation Compass. Army was in process of destruction throughout Q1 1941. Maletti Group included for completeness but destroyed December 9, 1940 before Q1 began. Final destruction occurred February 7, 1941 at Beda Fomm. This TO&E captures army at mid-campaign state, not final decimated state.
